canonical_explanation.text: Probability is a measure of the likelihood of an event occurring. The classical (theoretical) probability of an event E is defined as P(E) = Number of outcomes favourable to E / Total number of equally likely outcomes. The value of P(E) always lies between 0 and 1 inclusive, where 0 represents an impossible event and 1 represents a certain event.
rules: P(E) = Number of favourable outcomes / Total number of equally likely outcomes
P(E) + P(not E) = 1, i.e., P(complement) = 1 - P(E)
A standard die has 6 faces (1-6), a coin has 2 faces (Head, Tail), a deck has 52 cards (4 suits of 13 each)

questions.question_text: The probability of an event E is defined as:

options.text: Number of favourable outcomes / Total number of outcomes
Total number of outcomes / Number of favourable outcomes
Number of favourable outcomes × Total outcomes
Number of favourable outcomes − Total outcomes

questions.explanation_correct: By the classical definition, P(E) = Number of favourable outcomes / Total number of equally likely outcomes.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Probability is the ratio of favourable outcomes to total outcomes, not any other operation.

questions.question_text: The probability of any event E always lies between:
questions.explanation_correct: For any event E, 0 ≤ P(E) ≤ 1.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Probability values range from 0 (impossible) to 1 (certain), not beyond.

questions.question_text: If all outcomes of an experiment are equally likely, this approach to probability is called:
questions.explanation_correct: When all outcomes are equally likely, we use the classical or theoretical definition of probability.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Classical probability assumes equally likely outcomes, unlike experimental probability which uses observed frequencies.

questions.question_text: A random experiment is one where:

options.text: The outcome cannot be predicted with certainty
The outcome is always the same
There is only one possible outcome

questions.explanation_correct: A random experiment has multiple possible outcomes and the exact outcome cannot be predicted in advance.
questions.explanation_incorrect: In a random experiment, the result is uncertain — that is what makes it random.

questions.question_text: The set of all possible outcomes of a random experiment is called:
questions.explanation_correct: The sample space is the collection of all possible outcomes of an experiment.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A sample space contains every possible outcome. An event is a subset of the sample space.

questions.question_text: If P(E) = 0.3, then P(not E) is:
questions.explanation_incorrect: The probability of the complement of E is always 1 minus the probability of E.

questions.question_text: If P(not E) = 5/8, then P(E) equals:
questions.explanation_incorrect: Since P(E) + P(not E) = 1, we get P(E) = 1 − 5/8 = 3/8.

questions.question_text: P(E) + P(not E) is always equal to:
questions.explanation_correct: The sum of the probability of an event and its complement is always 1.
questions.explanation_incorrect: This is the complementary rule: P(E) + P(not E) = 1.

questions.question_text: The probability of winning a game is 0.45. What is the probability of losing?
questions.explanation_correct: P(losing) = 1 − P(winning) = 1 − 0.45 = 0.55.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Since winning and losing are complementary events, P(losing) = 1 − 0.45 = 0.55.

questions.question_text: If the probability that it will rain tomorrow is 0.72, the probability that it will not rain is:
questions.explanation_incorrect: Complementary probability: P(no rain) = 1 − P(rain) = 0.28.

questions.question_text: When a fair coin is tossed, the probability of getting a head is:
questions.explanation_correct: A fair coin has 2 equally likely outcomes: Head and Tail. P(Head) = 1/2.
questions.explanation_incorrect: There are 2 equally likely outcomes and 1 favourable, so P = 1/2.

questions.question_text: When a standard die is thrown, the total number of possible outcomes is:
questions.explanation_correct: A standard die has 6 faces numbered 1 to 6, so there are 6 possible outcomes.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A die has faces numbered 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6 — that is 6 outcomes.

questions.question_text: A standard deck of playing cards has how many cards?
questions.explanation_correct: A standard deck contains 52 cards: 13 cards in each of 4 suits (spades, hearts, diamonds, clubs).
questions.explanation_incorrect: A standard deck has 52 cards (excluding jokers).

questions.question_text: A die is thrown once. The probability of getting a number greater than 4 is:
questions.explanation_correct: Numbers greater than 4 are 5 and 6. P = 2/6 = 1/3.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Favourable outcomes = {5, 6} = 2. Total outcomes = 6. P = 2/6 = 1/3.

questions.question_text: A die is thrown once. The probability of getting an even number is:
questions.explanation_correct: Even numbers on a die: {2, 4, 6} = 3. P = 3/6 = 1/2.
questions.explanation_incorrect: There are 3 even numbers out of 6, so P = 3/6 = 1/2.

questions.question_text: A die is thrown once. The probability of getting a prime number is:
questions.explanation_correct: Prime numbers on a die: {2, 3, 5} = 3. P = 3/6 = 1/2.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Primes on a die are 2, 3, and 5. That is 3 out of 6 = 1/2.

questions.question_text: Two coins are tossed simultaneously. The probability of getting exactly one head is:
questions.explanation_correct: Sample space = {HH, HT, TH, TT}. Exactly one head: {HT, TH} = 2. P = 2/4 = 1/2.
questions.explanation_incorrect: With 2 coins, there are 4 outcomes. Exactly one head occurs in 2 of them, so P = 1/2.

questions.question_text: Two coins are tossed simultaneously. The probability of getting at least one head is:
questions.explanation_correct: Sample space = {HH, HT, TH, TT}. At least one head: {HH, HT, TH} = 3. P = 3/4.
questions.explanation_incorrect: P(at least one head) = 1 − P(no head) = 1 − 1/4 = 3/4.

questions.question_text: A card is drawn at random from a well-shuffled deck. The probability of getting a king is:
questions.explanation_correct: There are 4 kings in a deck of 52 cards. P = 4/52 = 1/13.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Kings = 4 out of 52 cards, so P = 4/52 = 1/13.

questions.question_text: A card is drawn at random from a deck of 52 cards. The probability of getting a red card is:
questions.explanation_correct: Red cards (hearts + diamonds) = 26. P = 26/52 = 1/2.
questions.explanation_incorrect: There are 26 red cards in a deck of 52, so P = 26/52 = 1/2.

questions.question_text: The probability of an impossible event is:
questions.explanation_correct: An impossible event can never occur, so its probability is 0.
questions.explanation_incorrect: If an event cannot happen, the number of favourable outcomes is 0, giving P = 0.

questions.question_text: The probability of a certain (sure) event is:
questions.explanation_correct: A certain event always occurs, so every outcome is favourable. P = Total/Total = 1.
questions.explanation_incorrect: P(certain event) = 1 because all outcomes are favourable.

questions.question_text: When a die is thrown, the probability of getting a number less than 7 is:
questions.explanation_correct: All faces {1,2,3,4,5,6} are less than 7. All 6 outcomes are favourable. P = 6/6 = 1. This is a certain event.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Every number on a die is less than 7, so this is a certain event with P = 1.

questions.question_text: When a die is thrown, the probability of getting the number 7 is:
questions.explanation_correct: A standard die has faces 1-6 only. Getting a 7 is impossible, so P = 0.
questions.explanation_incorrect: 7 is not on any face of a standard die, making it an impossible event.

questions.question_text: A bag contains 5 red, 3 blue and 2 green balls. A ball is drawn at random. The probability of getting a red ball is:
questions.explanation_correct: Total balls = 5 + 3 + 2 = 10. Red balls = 5. P = 5/10 = 1/2.

questions.question_text: A bag contains 4 white and 6 black balls. The probability of drawing a black ball is:
A card is drawn from a deck of 52 cards. The probability of drawing a face card is:
questions.explanation_correct: Face cards = Jack + Queen + King = 4 × 3 = 12. P = 12/52 = 3/13.
questions.explanation_incorrect: There are 12 face cards (J, Q, K in each of 4 suits). P = 12/52 = 3/13.

questions.question_text: A card is drawn at random from a deck of 52 cards. The probability of getting a spade is:
questions.explanation_correct: There are 13 spades in a deck of 52. P = 13/52 = 1/4.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Each suit has 13 cards. P(spade) = 13/52 = 1/4.

questions.question_text: A card is drawn at random from a deck of 52 cards. What is the probability of getting neither a king nor a queen?
questions.explanation_correct: Kings = 4, Queens = 4. Cards that are king or queen = 8. P(neither) = 1 − 8/52 = 44/52 = 11/13.
questions.explanation_incorrect: P(king or queen) = 8/52. So P(neither) = 1 − 8/52 = 44/52 = 11/13.

questions.question_text: A card is drawn from a deck of 52 cards. The probability that it is a black king is:
questions.explanation_correct: Black kings = King of Spades + King of Clubs = 2. P = 2/52 = 1/26.
questions.explanation_incorrect: There are only 2 black kings (spades and clubs). P = 2/52 = 1/26.

questions.question_text: A box contains 3 red, 4 blue and 5 green marbles. The probability of drawing a green marble is ___.
questions.explanation_incorrect: P(green) = number of green / total = 5/12.

questions.question_text: If P(E) = 7/12, then P(not E) = ___.
Three coins are tossed simultaneously. The probability of getting at most 2 heads is:
questions.explanation_correct: Total outcomes = 8 (HHH, HHT, HTH, THH, HTT, THT, TTH, TTT). At most 2 heads means all except HHH = 7. P = 7/8.
questions.explanation_incorrect: P(at most 2 heads) = 1 − P(3 heads) = 1 − 1/8 = 7/8.

questions.question_text: Two dice are thrown simultaneously. The total number of outcomes is:
questions.explanation_correct: Each die has 6 outcomes. Total = 6 × 6 = 36.
questions.explanation_incorrect: When two dice are thrown, outcomes = 6 × 6 = 36.

questions.question_text: Two dice are thrown simultaneously. The probability that the sum of the numbers is 7 is:
questions.explanation_incorrect: There are 6 pairs that give sum 7 out of 36 total outcomes. P = 6/36 = 1/6.

questions.question_text: Two dice are thrown. The probability that the sum is greater than 10 is:
Two dice are thrown simultaneously. The probability of getting a doublet (same number on both dice) is:
questions.explanation_incorrect: There are 6 doublets out of 36 outcomes. P = 6/36 = 1/6.

questions.question_text: A bag contains 12 balls of which x are white. If one ball is drawn at random, the probability of drawing a white ball is 1/3. The value of x is:
questions.explanation_incorrect: x/12 = 1/3 gives x = 4.

questions.question_text: Numbers 1 to 20 are written on separate slips and put in a box. One slip is drawn at random. The probability that the number on the slip is a multiple of 3 is:
questions.explanation_incorrect: There are 6 multiples of 3 between 1 and 20. P = 6/20 = 3/10.

questions.question_text: Numbers 1 to 15 are written on cards. A card is drawn at random. The probability that the number is a perfect square is:
questions.explanation_correct: Perfect squares from 1-15: {1, 4, 9} = 3. P = 3/15 = 1/5.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Perfect squares: 1, 4, 9 (note 16 > 15). So 3 out of 15 = 1/5.

questions.question_text: A card is drawn from a deck of 52 cards. The probability of getting an ace of hearts is:
questions.explanation_correct: There is only 1 ace of hearts in 52 cards. P = 1/52.
questions.explanation_incorrect: There is exactly one ace of hearts in the deck. P = 1/52.

questions.question_text: A card is drawn at random from a deck of 52 cards. The probability of drawing a card that is not a diamond is:
questions.explanation_correct: Diamonds = 13. Not diamond = 52 − 13 = 39. P = 39/52 = 3/4.

questions.question_text: The probability of drawing a red ball from a bag containing only blue balls is 0.
questions.explanation_correct: Since there are no red balls, drawing a red ball is impossible. P = 0.
questions.explanation_incorrect: An event that cannot occur has probability 0.

questions.question_text: If a bag contains 10 green balls and nothing else, the probability of drawing a green ball is 1.
questions.explanation_correct: Every ball is green, so drawing a green ball is a certain event. P = 10/10 = 1.
questions.explanation_incorrect: When all outcomes are favourable, the event is certain and P = 1.

questions.question_text: The probability of selecting a boy from a class is 3/5. If there are 40 students in the class, the number of girls is:
questions.explanation_incorrect: Boys = 24, so girls = 40 − 24 = 16.

questions.question_text: From a deck of 52 cards, the probability of drawing a card that is either a heart or a spade is:
questions.explanation_correct: Hearts = 13, Spades = 13. Total favourable = 26. P = 26/52 = 1/2.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Hearts + Spades = 26 cards. P = 26/52 = 1/2.

questions.question_text: Probability can be negative.
questions.explanation_correct: This is false. Probability always lies between 0 and 1 inclusive and can never be negative.
questions.explanation_incorrect: P(E) is always ≥ 0, so probability cannot be negative.

questions.question_text: The probability of any event is always greater than or equal to 0 and less than or equal to 1.
questions.explanation_correct: By definition, 0 ≤ P(E) ≤ 1 for any event E.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Probability is bounded between 0 and 1 inclusive.

questions.question_text: A bag contains 8 red, 5 white and 7 black balls. A ball is drawn at random. The probability that the ball drawn is not black is ___.
questions.explanation_correct: Total = 20. Not black = 8 + 5 = 13. P = 13/20.
questions.explanation_incorrect: P(not black) = (total − black)/total = 13/20.

questions.question_text: Two dice are thrown. The probability that the product of the numbers on the two dice is 12 is ___.
